Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Installation of a Real-Time Seafloor Geodetic and Thermal Observatory on the Cascadia Subduction Zone
Award.AbstractNarration: The Principal Investigators will install instrumentation to observe strain build-up and fluid behavior near the up-dip end of the Cascadia Subduction Zone. The project will establish a borehole geodetic observatory offshore of Vancouver adjacent to an existing CORK observatory, which will be enhanced with tiltmeters and temperature-monitoring instrumentation. Real-time data will be streamed onshore and made available to the community via the NEPTUNE Canada system. Long-term data analysis goals include capturing and characterizing slow-slip events and/or major earthquakes. The project will enhance scientific infrastructure and produce widely accessible data that will advance understanding of earthquake and tsunami hazards. A graduate student at RSMAS will be supported and at WHOI students and/or post-doctoral researchers will be involved in the cruise and data analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this grant was to procure and install a long-term downhole temperature monitoring system in a scientific research borehole (called “U1364A”) drilled in 2010 by the Integrated Ocean Drilling Program (IODP) offshore Vancouver Island above the tectonically active Cascadia subduction zone.  This was a collaborate project with investigators at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution who obtained independent funding for seismic and deformation in the same hole and provided system integration of the temperature data into a real-time data stream to shore via the Ocean Networks Canada (ONC) cabled seafloor observatory in the region.  The technical objectives were fully achieved in two main stages.  First, the integrated temperature/seismic/deformation instrument string was successfully installed in the hole in July of 2016, using the US research vessel Sikuliaq and the remotely-operated vehicle Jason.  Second, connection to the ONC cabled observatory was achieved in June of 2017, a few weeks before the formal end date of this project, 31 July 2017.  When the connection was made and power applied to the instrumentation, the data started being logged to and archived on the ONC database.  This includes the borehole temperatures supported by this project, at intervals of every minute.  Those data are freely available to the all scientific and public users via the following URL: http://dmas.uvic.ca/DataSearch?location=CQS64&deviceCategory=BHTL

In more detail, Hole U1364A penetrates about 300 meters below seafloor near the leading edge of the North American plate, under which the Pacific plate is being subducted.  At the time the hole was drilled, it was also instrumented with a formation pressure monitoring capability at four independent depths below seafloor.  This capability will allow for monitoring of pressure signals that reflect deformation of the North American plate due to the tectonic forces as the two plate converge.  In addition, the hole penetrates through a section that is notable for the presence of frozen gas hydrates, dominantly methane hydrates, that are geologically stable at limited ranges of temperature and pressure.  The temperature-monitoring system was designed with 24 sensors (called thermistors) from seafloor to 268 m below seafloor (see attached summary figure).  The sensor spacings are concentrated at three of the pressure-monitoring zones as well as the shallow limit of the gas hydrate stability zone, which is marked by a seismic reflector that mimics the seafloor and is therefore called a bottom-simulating reflector or BSR.  The combination of pressure and temperature monitoring will allow resolution of in situ values and temporal changes in the gas hydrate stability zone that might be due to active flow of formation fluids beneath the seafloor.  Adding the seismic and deformation monitoring capabilities of the Woods Hole instrumentation makes this a valuable installation for monitoring of deformation of the North American plate and the Cascadia earthquake seismic cycle – an important societal contribution in terms of monitoring geological hazards in the heavily populated northwest US/southeast Canada region near the Cascadia subduction zone.  

As the ONC connection was not made until just before the end of this project, there has not been sufficient time for full analysis of the initial data stream and publication of any scientific conclusions.  Nevertheless, data from all of the sensors in the integrated instrumentation system seem to be of good quality, showing strong promise to fulfill for many years the overall objectives encapsulated in the title of the project: Installation of a Real-Time Seafloor Geodetic and Thermal Observatory on the Cascadia Subduction Zone.
